questions.text: A 25-year-old patient comes with recurrent vesicular rash on lips. Soon he develops a pruritic rash that began on the extremities especially the palms and soles and then spreads on the trunk. He was given acyclovir for the same. Her temperature is 38.1 °C. Examination of the skin lesions reveals dusky center and a lighter color around it. The final outer area appears to be erythematous. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herpes simplex The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Herpes simplex infection: Eczema herpeticum Eczema herpeticum: Disseminated HSV-1 infection. Aka Kaposi varicelliform eruption Predisposing factors: Atopic dermatitis, sezary syndrome, Darier disease Hailey-Hailey disease, ichthyosis vulgaris, psoriasis and drug eruption high IgE level, antibodies against Malassezia sympodialis, low NK cell count, low levels of cathelicidin LL37 and human β-defensin abnormalities in the interferon pathway Characteristic lesions: Vesicular and ulcerative (commonly) Folliculitis, minor 'frictional ulcers' ( rare) The vesicles burst to form erosions covered by haemorrhagic crusts. The disorder can be prevented by preventing children with atopic dermatitis from coming into contact with individuals with cold sores. Treatment: Oozing and crusted areas need to be gently bathed with saline. Acyclovir should be given as early as possible orally. It can also be administered intravenously. Famciclovir is a similar drug that can be used. Some clinicians would also favour giving prophylactic antibiotics at the same time. Underlying eczema needs to be treated with corticosteroids of sufficient strength to suppress the inflammation.

Highyeild:

- Herpes virus infection Virus - DNA Viruses, multiply within the nucleus -HSV-1 disease: Above the diaphragm Orolabial herpes Herpetic gingivostomatitis Herpetic whitlow Erythema multiforme Eczema herpeticum Mollaret meningitis - HSV-2 disease: Below the diaphragm Genital herpes with bilateral enlarged and tender inguinal lymph nodes Primary lesions: Vesicles Multiple grouped tender ulcer Ulcers with polycyclic margins

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Herpes zoster : aka shingles , is a viral syndrome caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus after an episode of varicella (chicken-pox). In the skin, the virus causes local inflammation and blistering. Option C. Measles virus: Caused by an RNA virus. The clinical picture of measles can be divided into three stages: prodromal, eruptive, and convalescent. The eruptive is characterized by the appearance of a maculopapular rash, initially fine that subsequently becomes confluent which begins behind the auricle and the presence of Koplik’s spot in buccaneers mucosa. Option D. HIV: Rarely produces pruritic papular eruptions.

questions.text: Imiquimod used in treatment of anogenital warts acts mainly as:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immunostimulator Treatment

Extraedge:

Anogenital warts transmission is usually by sexual route HPV 6 > HPV 11 Pointed masses on genitalia Application of acetic acid to genital warts enhances visualization of the lesions by making them white (aceto-whitening) Prevention of genital wart is only by Gardasil HPV vaccine, not by Cervarix vaccine.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady came to the OPD with a lesion on her upper lip as shown below. The lesions were painful earlier but now crusting in some places and seem to be increasing by scratching. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herpes labialis The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Herpes labialis. aka Cold sores/ Fever blister Caused by HSV-1 Site: Lip margin Characteristics: Fluid-filled vesicle s May be painful just at the onset of pain and may last for a few days. Itching or burning precedes by an hour or two the development of small closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base. Recurrences tend to be in the same region , but not always on the identical site. Fever, pain, and lymphangitis may be present Treatment: Mild or infrequent herpes labialis may need no treatment. Severe or troublesome recurrence: Acyclovir, Valacyclovir or Famciclovir.

Highyeild:

- Herpes virus infection Virus - DNA Virus, multiply within the nucleus -HSV-1 disease: Above the diaphragm Orolabial herpes Herpetic gingivostomatitis Herpetic whitlow Erythema multiforme Eczema herpeticum Mollaret meningitis - HSV-2 disease: Below the diaphragm Genital herpes with bilateral enlarged and tender inguinal lymph nodes Primary lesions: Vesicles Multiple grouped tender ulcer Ulcers with polycyclic margins

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Molluscum contagiosum: Multiple, pearly white, dome-shaped, umbilicated papules caused by a pox virus. Option B. Insect bite: Pruritic eruption at site of bite including local erythema, wheals, and urticaria Option D. Facial acne: Hair follicles under the skin become clogged with sebum and dead skin cells forming small, red, tender pamphlets and pustules

questions.text: Low risk HPV is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HPV 11 HPV 11 is low risk HPV and causes condyloma acuminata

Highyeild:

Low risk vs high risk HPVs Low-risk HPV types High-risk types HPV 6,11—causes genital warts HPV-16,-18, -45, -31, -33, -52 and -58 causes cervical warts * In high risk genital HPV types, E6 and E7 gene products bind and inactivate p53 (tumor suppressor gene) and retinoblastoma protein (pRb), respectively causing carcinogenesis

questions.text: Which of the following rash is mainly on extremities (acral)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Secondary syphilis The characteristic rash of secondary syphilis may appear as rough, red, or reddish-brown spots with scales both on the palms of the hands and the bottoms of the feet.

Highyeild:

Centripetal rash (Primarily central/truncal) Mnemonic: “Red Rashes Scare Parents Very Much” Centrifugal rash (Primarily on extremities) Mnemonic: You drive CARS with your Hands and Feet Rubella CA- Coxsackie A virus (Hand, foot, mouth disease) Roseola R—Rocky Mountain spotted fever Parvovirus B19 (Erythema infectiosum) S- Scarlet fever Varicella Measles

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Varicella is mainly a central rash sparing the hands and soles. The rash is vesicular, pustular, crusted with fever and malaise. Option C- Measles symptoms appear 7 to 14 days after contact with the virus and typically include high fever, cough, runny nose, and watery eyes. Measles rash appears 3 to 5 days after the first symptoms. The rash of measles starts on the face and behind the ears before spreading to the trunk. Option D- The rash of rubella consists of minute, discrete macules, in contrast to the confluent rash of measles. The rash appears within 24 hours of onset prodromal symptoms, spreads rapidly from face to trunk and proximal extremities and disappears altogether by the third day.

questions.text: A mother brought her child to OPD with the complaint lesion on the trunk as shown. What is true about the diagnosis of the below lesion?

options.label: C
options.text: Trichloroacetic acid is used for treatment

questions.correct_answer: C. Trichloroacetic acid is used for treatment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trichloroacetic acid is used for treatment The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mollusucum contagiosum. Molluscum Contagiosum Cause: Pox virus- Molluscum contagiosum virus Incubation period: 2 weeks Mode of spread: Direct skin-to-skin contact Indirect contact via shared towels or other items Auto-inoculation into another site by scratching or shaving: pseudo koebner's phenomenon Sexual transmission in adults Characteristics: Multiple, pearly white, dome-shaped papules which are umbilicated Under a hand lens, may have a mosaic appearance On piercing the umbilicated centre, white cheesy material can be extruded Diagnosis: By dermatoscopy and skin biopsy: shows characteristics intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. Henderson Peterson bodies Treatment: Hydrogen peroxide cream/povidone-iodine Cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid and diluted liquefied phenol are strong irritants which can both cause pain, blistering and scarring but with careful application and appropriate dilution can increase lesion clearance. Topical salicylic acid preparations, tretinoin, adapalene, nitric oxide cream and 5–10% potassium hydroxide solution and benzoyl peroxide cream. Treatment ladder First line Caustic destruction: cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid, diluted liquefied phenol Irritant: salicylic acid, adapalene, nitric oxide cream, potassium hydroxide, benzoyl peroxide, lemon myrtle oil, tea tree oil Surgical irritation Second line Immunological: diphencyprone, imiquimod, interferon, cimetidine, intralesional immunotherapy Surgical removal Third line Cidofovir Paclitaxel

Highyeild:

Strains of Molluscum contagiosum virus: Virus Age Site MCV-1 Children Face MCV-2 Adults Genitals

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came to the OPD with painful feet and complains of a lesion on her foot. She took many over-the-counter medications that were not useful. The biopsy was done and shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Warts The given clinical picture is suggestive of Warts: Cause: HPV infection- DNA virus Warts can be classified as The above picture is of Plantar wart: A plantar wart at first appears as a small shining ‘sago‐grain ’ papule, but soon assumes the typical appearance of sharply defined rounded lesion Site : beneath pressure points, the heel or the metatarsal heads. Pain is a common symptom but mosaic patterns are often painless If the surface is gently pared with a scalpel, the abrupt separation between the wart tissue and the protective horny ring becomes more obvious, as the epithelial ridges of the plantar skin are not continued over the surface of the wart. HPE : Koilocytes seen Spontaneous regression is more common in children than adults Treatment of HPV infection: Topical lactic acid, salicylic acid Electrocautery Cryotherapy

Highyeild:

HPV strains Disease HPV type associated with the disease Cutaneous Plantar Wart 1,2 Common Wart 2,1 Flat Wart 3,10 Butcher's wart 7,2 Genital Bowen's disease (intraepithelial neoplasm) 16 (Genital) 2, 3, 4, 16 (Extragenital) Epidermodysplasia verruciformis (full skin thickness wart can become squamous cell cancer) 2, 3, 5, 8, 9 10, 12, 14, 15, 17 Condylomata acuminata (venereal or genital warts) 6,11 Intraepithelial neoplasms Low grade 6, 11 High grade 16, 18 Respiratory papillomatosis (transmitted from mother to baby) 6,11

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option Lichen planus: Autoimmune disease with plain, purple, polygonal, pruritic papules. Mucosa shows a white lacy pattern. Nails have wing-shaped extensions of proximal nail folds called pterygium. Option Corn: aka Heloma or focal intractable plantar hyperkeratosis. Usually present as flesh-coloured dry, hard, rough papules with a whitish centre (called the core). They are located over a bony prominence and are painful on walking or standing. Option Plantar psoriasis: It is a papulosquamous disorder which consists of an erythematous plaque with silvery white scaling.

questions.text: A lady of 26 year old came to the OPD with the below lesion on her hand and is worried about the same. These are painful sometimes. The following can be used for treatment for the same except
questions.correct_answer: B. Acyclovir 500 mg TDS for 2 weeks
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acyclovir 500 mg TDS for 2 weeks Three given clinical pictures of the Acyclovir has no role in the treatment of the same. Warts: Cause: HPV infection- DNA virus Warts can be classified as Treatment of HPV infection: Topical lactic acid, salicylic acid Electrocautery Cryotherapy / radiofrequency ablation Gentle reduction of the layer of the hyperkeratotic epidermis by regular filing or paring down will usually make the lesion more comfortable.

Highyeild:

HPV strains Disease HPV type associated with the disease Cutaneous Plantar Wart 1,2 Common Wart 2,1 Flat Wart 3,10 Butcher's wart 7,2 Genital Bowen's disease (intraepithelial neoplasm) 16 (Genital) 2, 3, 4, 16 (Extragenital) Epidermodysplasia verruciformis (full skin thickness wart can become squamous cell cancer) 2, 3, 5, 8, 9 10, 12, 14, 15, 17 Condylomata acuminata (venereal or genital warts) 6,11 Intraepithelial neoplasms Low grade 6, 11 High grade 16, 18 Respiratory papillomatosis (transmitted from mother to baby) 6,11

questions.text: A 13 -year-old boy has complained repeatedly that he has a ‘sore bottom’. The perianal region has a few raised areas. Also on asking there is a history of sexual abuse. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perianal warts The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Perianal/ Anogenital warts. Warts: Cause: HPV infection- DNA virus Warts can be classified as Anogenital warts: Cause: Low fish HPV- 6,11 Characteristics: Large malodorous masses which may form on vulvar and perianal skin Some lesions are flat, though more conspicuous than plane warts elsewhere, generally on non‐mucosal surfaces such as the penile shaft, pubic skin, perianal skin and groins HPE: Shows extreme acanthosis and papillomatosis Horny layer is parakeratotic Treatment of HPV infection: Topical lactic acid, salicylic acid Electrocautery Cryotherapy

Highyeild:

Condyloma accuminata condyloma lata caused by HPV 6>11 Treponema pallidum- Secondary syphilis Easily bleeds on touch No bleeding Rough, verrucous, dry flat and moist soft, pedunculated induration, sessile Dark ground examination: Negative positive Treatment: Podophyllum resin 25% in alcohol Penicillin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Seborrhoeic keratosis: These are benign epidermal skin tumours that typically present above 50 years which can occur anywhere in the body. They have a dull, waxy, verrucous surface resulting in their characteristic “stuck on” appearance. They are light to dark brown, yellow, and grey, and they can present as isolated lesions to tens or even hundreds of lesions. Option B. Verrucous carcinoma: It is rare, locally aggressive, clinically exophytic, low-grade, slow-growing, well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with minimal metastatic potential. Manifests as cauliflower-like growth. Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum: caused by Chlamydia trachomatis which presents with a single painless transient ulcer and unilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Extraedge:

HPV strains Disease HPV type associated with the disease Cutaneous Plantar Wart 1,2 Common Wart 2,1 Flat Wart 3,10 Butcher's wart 7,2 Genital Bowen's disease (intraepithelial neoplasm) 16 (Genital) 2, 3, 4, 16 (Extragenital) Epidermodysplasia verruciformis (full skin thickness wart can become squamous cell cancer) 2, 3, 5, 8, 9 10, 12, 14, 15, 17 Condylomata acuminata (venereal or genital warts) 6,11 Intraepithelial neoplasms Low grade 6, 11 High grade 16, 18 Respiratory papillomatosis (transmitted from mother to baby) 6,11

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with the below lesion. The child had a mild fever. And after that developed oval vesicles on the palms and slightly less on the sole. And now is beginning to fade on itself. What is the disease?
questions.correct_answer: A. Hand, foot and mouth disease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hand, foot and mouth disease The given clinical picture is suggestive of Hand, foot and mouth disease Cause: Coxsackie A16 Enterovirus Characteristics: Vesiculopapular lesions located in the hand, feet and mouth in child In children, the onset is often with a low‐grade fever, sore throat and malaise but in adults, painful stomatitis is an early feature. Site: sides or backs of the fingers and toes (around the nails and the margins of the heels) finger flexures, on the palms and soles and sometimes in the buttocks. They are usually few in number but rarely up to 50. Outbreaks in school are common. Treatment: Self-limiting They fade after 2–3 days (Infection can be subclinical).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Chicken pox: caused by VZV. The rash begins as macules, and rapidly progresses to papules, followed by a vesicular stage and crusting of lesions. Crusts slough off after 1 to 2 weeks. Option C. Molluscum Contagiosum: caused by pox virus with Multiple, pearly white, dome-shaped papules which are umbilicated. Option D. Secondary syphilis: Characterised by condyloma lata, copper red papules, snail track ulcers with systemic involvement.

Extraedge:

Diseases causing Rash on palms and soles Mnemonic: CARS CA- Coxsackie virus A R- Rocky mountain spotted fever S- Secondary syphilis

questions.text: A patient who is 24 years old has been admitted to an emergency with complaints of high fever, myalgia and marked hypotension and on lab test deranged CBC. Fluids have been given. The patient is responding well to fluids and analgesic medication but the doctor observed the rash on the body and on applying the BP cuff bleeding points were seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dengue The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Dengue Showing a positive tourniquet test. Dengue: Cause: Dengue virus - Flavivirus Transmitted by: Aedes mosquito Clinical presentation: Dengue fever : Fever, rash, headache, myalgia, arthralgia, neutropenia Dengue Hemorrhagic fever : Dengue fever + bleeding and plasma leakage due to thrombocytopenia Dengue shock syndrome: circulatory collapse because of plasma leakage

Highyeild:

Dengue and skin eruption: It begins between day 3 to day 5 of illness, often as the fever defervescence. Lesions are macular or morbilliform and are usually confluent, characteristically sparing small islands of normal skin—“ islands of white in a sea of red” . Often generalised (50%) or involves only the extremities (30%) or the trunk (20%). Persistent blanching after pressing the skin can also be seen. Positive tourniquet test: Involves taking the blood pressure, leaving the cuff inflated for 5 minutes, waiting 2 minutes, and counting petechiae; 10 or more per square inch is considered positive. Facial flushing may be prominent. The rash is either asymptomatic or only mildly pruritic.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Sandfly lesion: Sandfly cause leishmaniasis. Cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by oriental sores Option B. Psoriasis: It is a papulosquamous disorder which consists of an erythematous plaque with silvery white scaling. Option D. Herpes: Herpes infection causes vesiculopapular eruptions.

questions.text: The patient had a below lesion on the tongue with projections and plaque . The patient has very recently started on HAART therapy. The lesion could not be scraped off. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral hairy leukoplakia The given clinical picture is of Oral hairy leukoplakia. Cause: Epstein-Barr virus infection of the tongue Occurs due to reactivation of EBV infection and usually occurs in association with immunodeficiency due to HIV infection, patients on immunosuppressants or with any haematological malignancy. Clinical features: Asymptomatic white plaques on the lateral surface of the tongue that cannot be wiped off. Appearance: Corrugated or shaggy/ faint white streaks May be associated with discomfort, burning or stinging sensation. In more advanced diseases, the plaques may extend over the tongue and into the oro‐pharynx. Treatment: Topical retinoids acid, gentian violet, 25% podophyllin resin Acyclovir Antiretroviral therapy in those with HIV-associated OHL Surgical excision

Highyeild:

EBV infection can cause: Infectious mononucleosis/kissing s’ disease - Triad of pharyngitis, fever, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy Burkitt’s lymphoma Hodgkin Lymphoma Nasopharyngeal Ca (NPC): Trotter’s triad Oral hairy leukoplakia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Oral candidiasis: Acute pseudomembranous candidiasis is characterised by white patches on gums, tongue and inside the mouth that can be peeled off. Option C. Lichen planus: Autoimmune disease with plain, purple, polygonal, pruritic papules. Mucosa shows a white lacy pattern. Nails have a wing-shaped extension of the proximal nail fold called pterygium. Option D. SCC: Squamous cell ca of the oral cavity may appear as areas of erythroplakia or leukoplakia and may be exophytic or ulcerated. Cancers are often indurated and firm with a rolled border.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male diabetic presents with fever and painful vesicles and ulcers over lips. The lesions are shown in the image below. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herpes simplex The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Herpetic gingivostomatitis. Cause: HSV-1 Features: Vesicles that rupture to form erosions covered by membrane Associated with high-grade fever and constitutional symptoms More common in children Can be sexually transmitted/ direct contact HPE of mucosal Herpetic infection: Degeneration of stratified squamous epithelial cells Acantholysis Formation of an inflammatory infiltrate around capillaries of dermis Cowdry A bodies Complication: Dehydration Herpes labialis HSV encephalitis Herpetic whitlow Herpetic keratitis Eczema herpeticum Treatment: Acyclovir

Highyeild:

- Herpes virus infection Virus DNA Virus, multiply within the nucleus HSV-1 disease: Above the diaphragm Orolabial herpes Herpetic gingivostomatitis Herpetic whitlow Erythema multiforme Eczema herpeticum Mollaret meningitis HSV-2 disease: Below the diaphragm Genital herpes with bilateral enlarged and tender inguinal lymph nodes Primary lesions: Vesicles Multiple grouped tender ulcer Ulcers with polycyclic margins

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Herpes zoster: -It occurs in reactivation of latent varicella zoster from dorsal root ganglion after primary infection- chicken pox characterised by grouped vesicles on red base with dermatomal involvement. Option C. Varicella zoster: Caused chicken pox with features of rash having dew drop on rose petal appearance Option D. HFMD: Vesiculopapular lesions located in the hand, feet and mouth in children caused by Coxsackie A16 virus.

questions.text: Multiple erythematous annular lesions with peripheral collarette of scales arranged predominantly on trunk are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pityriasis rosea Pityriasis = powdery scale, rosea = pink Etiology: HHV-7 > HHV-6 Clinical: Common acute disease typically beginning as a single oval scaly plaque on the trunk (“herald patch” or “mother patch”) The initial lesion is followed later by the appearance of numerous similar-appearing smaller lesions located along the lines of cleavage (along the ribs) This is called Christmas tree or fir-tree pattern. Typically, the periphery of the lesions has a collarette scale (‘collar’= something on periphery, ‘ette’= small)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Pityriasis versicolor presents as perifollicular hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules on chest and back. It has fine scaling on scratching Option C- Tinea will not only be on trunk and will not have collarette scales Option D- Hansen will not have scaling, though BB Hansen does have annular lesions.

questions.text: A farmer came to OPD with painful nodules on his fingers. The physician diagnosed it as Milker’s nodules. What is not true about the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

RNA virus Milkers nodule: aka pseudocowpox It is an occupational viral infection transmitted by direct contact from infected cows. Cause: Parapoxvirus ( ds DNA virus) Incubation period: 5 to 14 days Features: Initially small, red, raised, flat-topped spots appear Within a week, they change to red-blue, firm, slightly tender blisters or nodules (lumps) which become crusted Site: Usually on fingers. Can occur in the face also. Secondary bacterial infection can occur Patient can develop lymphangitis Prevention: Treat cows' mastitis, use gloves, soap, water, and disinfectants before and after handling these animals. They resolve spontaneously.

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have a viral infection. On histology, ballooning is seen. This is likely to be due to
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herpes zoster “Intracellular edema” of cells is called ballooning. It is observed characteristically in infections by some viruses, such as those of herpes, pox, and Coxsackie.

Random:

Explanation of incorrect options: Option B : Warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and typically present as raised growths on the skin. Ballooning degeneration is not a characteristic histological finding associated with warts. Option C : Pityriasis rosea is a common, self-limiting skin condition characterized by a herald patch followed by a rash of smaller, scaly patches. It is not typically associated with ballooning degeneration on histology. Option D : Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fever, rash, and muscle pain. Ballooning degeneration is not a histological feature commonly associated with dengue infection.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a rare disease -Trichodysplasia spinulosa. What is the causative organism ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Polyomavirus Trichodysplasia spinulosa It is a rare disfiguring condition caused by infection of the inner root sheath of hair Cause: Polyomavirus, often in immunocompromised patients Characteristics: Shiny, follicular papules with keratotic spikes seen over the face. Alopecia of eyebrows and scalp can also occur HPE: Large and distended hair follicles, which are often plugged with keratin and other debris. Treatment: Topical cidofovir cream Oral valganciclovir

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option Pox virus: It causes cowpox, Molluscum contagiosum, and smallpox (eradicated). Option Picorna virus: causes poliomyelitis, HFMD, hepatitis, etc Option Herpes virus: Can cause herpes labialis, genital herpes, shingles, mononucleosis, etc

questions.text: A 16-years old girl comes to the physician with fever, fatigue and sore throat for 8 days. She also has a diffuse rash that started yesterday. Three days ago she took amoxicillin that she has at home. On examination, she had a morbilliform rash over her trunk and extremities, tonsillar enlargement and tender cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly present. Blood reports showed leukocytosis. Which of the following is most likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heterophile antibody test The given clinical scenario with Fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis are all indicative of infectious mononucleosis , which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus . Infectious mononucleosis: aka kissing’s disease Caused by: EBV (HHV 4) common in teens and young adults Pathogenesis: EBV spread through body fluids mainly saliva which insect B cells via CD21 receptor. Infected B cells are induced to undergo significant proliferation of CD8 cytotoxic T cells specific for viral antigens expressed as MHC class 1/peptide complexes on B cells Clinical features: Fever Hepatosplenomegaly Pharyngitis Lymphadenopathy Risk of splenic rupture Diagnosis: Monospot positive- heterophile agglutination test Peripheral smear: Downey cells Use of amoxicillin can cause maculopapular rash

Highyeild:

EBV infection can cause: Infectious mononucleosis/kissings’ disease - Triad of pharyngitis, fever, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy Burkitt’s lymphoma Hodgkin Lymphoma Nasopharyngeal Ca (NPC) : Trotter’s triad Oral hairy leukoplakia EBV infects B cells and Downey cells are T cells.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a recurrent vesicular genital rash comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a painful, pruritic rash that began on the extremities and has spread to her trunk. Her only medication is acyclovir. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Examination of the skin shows several reddish-purple papules and macules, some of which have a dusky centre with a lighter ring around them. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Erythema multiforme The given clinical scenario with the patient having recurrent genital HSV and a painful exanthem with target lesions most likely has Erythema multiforme (EM). Erythema multiforme: It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction of the skin Triggers: Infections: HSV , Mycoplasma pneumonia Medications: beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, phenytoin Characteristics: Can occur as a macule, Papules, vesicles that typically progress to target lesions Spread proximally from the back of hands and feet Nikolsky sign is negative

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Eczema herpeticum: Disseminated HSV-1 infection. Associated with Underlying diseases like Atopic dermatitis, sezary syndrome, and Darier disease characterised by a vesicular and ulcerative rash. Option C. Urticaria: It is characterised by very itchy weals (hives), with or without surrounding erythematous flares. Each weal may last a few minutes or several hours and may change shape. Weals may be round, or form rings, a map-like pattern, or giant patches. Option D. Stevens-Johnson syndrome: Potentially fatal skin reaction involving the skin, and mucosal membrane accompanied by systemic symptoms. Often caused by drugs like anticonvulsants, antimicrobials

questions.text: A 25 year pregnant women presents with a growing vulval warty lesion to you. The best treatment would be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trichloroacetic acid Trichloroacetic acid is corrosive to the skin and mucous membranes and destroys condyloma acuminata by chemical coagulation of cellular proteins, resulting in tissue necrosis. Trichloroacetic acid is safe for pregnant women because it is not absorbed by the skin or mucous membranes. Cesarean delivery is indicated for women with anogenital warts if the pelvic outlet is obstructed or if vaginal delivery would result in excessive bleeding.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B &C- Podophyllin and Podophyllotoxin are contraindicated during pregnancy Option D- Data from studies of human participants are limited regarding use of imiquimod during pregnancy

questions.text: Varicella developing in vaccine receivers is known as:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breakthrough varicella Occurs in approximately 20% of the vaccine receiver

Highyeild:

Varicella/Chicken pox -Cause: Varicella zoster virus (HHV3) -Incubation period: 10 to 21 days -Features: Rash appears on 1st day of fever The rash is pleomorphic, giving dew drops on rose petal appearance: superficial and thin-walled surrounded by erythema. It begins as macules which become papules and ultimately change to vesicular rash which then forms brownish scabs Centripetal pattern: Begins in the trunk and then spreads to the face and extremities The rash lasts for 3 to 15 days. -Infectivity: 1 day before rash till all vesicles form scabs -Complication: The virus can remain latent in dorsal root pr trigeminal ganglion and can reactivate to cause Shingles.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Varicella bullosa: vesicle of varicella enlarges into large bulla and become haemorrhagic and rupture, which is termed as varicella bullosa and it develops due to superinfection with toxin-producing S. aureus. Option C. Varicella gangrenosa: cutaneous gangrene that follows secondary infection following varicella Option D. Haemorrhagic varicella: occurs in malnutrition and immunocompromised patients

questions.text: Match the following: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-d, B-b, C-a, D-c Warts: Cause: HPV infection- DNA virus Warts can be classified as: HPE : Koilocytes seen Treatment of HPV infection: Topical lactic acid, salicylic acid Electrocautery Cryotherapy

Highyeild:

Epidermodysplasia verruciformis -Rare, autosomal recessive inherited skin disorder characterised by a chronic eruption of brownish plaques. -Cause: HPV 5,8,10 and 47 Bushke Löwenstein tumours: Giant condyloma acuminata. It is a slow-growing verrucous tumour of the penis and anogenital region which can grow up to twenty centimetres in size and can locally destroy contiguous structures -Cause: HPV 6, 11

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the physician because of a generalized nonpruritic rash for 2 days. The rash began on her trunk and spread to her extremities. Five days ago, she was taken to the emergency department for a fever of 40.5°C (104.9°F) and a 1-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She was born at term and has no history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Examination shows a maculopapular rash that blanches on pressure. A photograph of the rash is shown. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Roseola infantum The given clinical scenario is of Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum) Roseola infantum: Cause: HHV 6 Characteristics: Usually seen in children <2 years 3-day fever (causing a tonic-clonic febrile seizure in this child) Blanching, maculopapular, non-pruritic rash Rash appears mainly on the trunk but may spread to the face and extremities. Associated with cervical, postauricular, and/or occipital lymphadenopathy. Nagayama spots Treatment: self-limiting

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Kawasaki disease: Acute, self-limited medium vessel vasculitis characterised by Conjunctivitis, Polymorphous desquamating rash, Strawberry tongue, Hand-foot changes (Edema), and fever Option B. Drug allergy: The reaction cannot be explained on the basis of known pharmacologic or idiosyncratic effects of the drugs. In the absence of prior exposure, the reaction occurs after 7 to 10 days on the drug. With prior sensitization, an anaphylactic reaction usually occurs within 30 minutes and other "accelerated" reactions within 2 to 4 days. Option C. Impetigo: Symptoms include red, itchy sores that break open and leak a clear fluid or pus for a few days. Next, a crusty yellow or “honey-coloured” scab forms over the sore, which then heals without leaving a scar.
